titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Visits this morning to Mr: Smith and Mr: Maclure, Mr: Fisher and Mr: Graham, none of whom were at their lodgings— They all dined with us; together with Mr: Harris— I took a long walk; and read Massillon’s Easter-day Sermon, on the ordinary causes of religious relapses— The ladies paid a visit in the Evening to Madame de Bray; and the Gentlemen went to Mrs: Krehmer’s—

2. Spent the morning in reading my father’s letters published since I left America, in the file of the Boston Patriot, which I received while unable to read them, owing to the inflammation of my eye— Afterwards walked upon the Fontanka, and through the Newsky Perspective— Evening at home, and at Chess.— Mr: Harris paid us a visit.

3. At Noon Mr: Harris called on me with Mr: Grootten; a German at the head of the Cotton Manufactury, worked by orphan children— I afterwards went with Mr: Harris and visited Mr: Telisius and Captain Krusenstern— Mr: Fuss was not at home— Mr: Telisius was complaining much of the want of patronage for objects of Science & Art here— He says they employed only Scholars to engrave his drawings, which accompany the voyage—that they spoiled his drawings, and did not engrave them well— He therefore doubts whether any English or French translation of the work will appear. The Emperor, pays entirely for the plates of the Russian Work; which have cost him 100,000 Roubles— But the mere paper upon which they are struck off, has risen so much in price, that they cannot afford to give it good; and use mean paper which is another disgrace to the work— The Russian Edition is of 1000 Copies; of which not a hundred will ever be read; and the German Edition so small, that there are no copies left for new Subscribers— Mr: Telisius gave me; for he would not allow me to pay for it, his own copy of the first volume; and has taken my name down as a subscriber for the remaining volumes— The Dissertation upon the Mammoth, he thinks will not be published at-all.— Captain Krusenstern is here on a visit— He commands the Blagodat, the largest ship in the Russian Navy; and perhaps in the world— He has been many years in England; and two or three in America— After these visits, walking on the Quay, I met General Pardo, who turned and walked with me upwards of an hour— His conversation is always agreeable— This day it was chiefly on political topics— Mr: J. S. Smith & Mr: Maclure spent part of the Evening with us— We had Cards & Chess.

4. Visit this morning to Mr: J. S. Smith and Mr: Maclure, whom I did not find at home— Walk on the Quay and the Fontanka Canal; where I met Mr: Navarro— Reading the Voyage de deux Français dans le Nord de l’Europe— Mr: Smith, Mr: Fisher and Mr: Graham, spent part of the Evening with us— Pass’d the rest at our ordinary Amusements. We have now a succession of beautiful weather— Clear Sky—5 or 6 degrees of frost by Reaumur in the Night—and as many of thaw with the Sun, in the day time— In the shade it still freezes, the day through.

5. Visited at Mr: Glukoff’s; but he was not at home— I saw Captain Beckford who had just arrived from Cronstadt. My object was to make enquiries for some pieces of sheeting to send to my mother, Mrs: Cranch, and Mrs: Welsh; which are to be sent down to Cronstadt before the breaking up of the river. Called at Mr: Raimbert’s, to thank him for his manuscripts respecting the cultivation of hemp— Walk untill near five O’Clock— Mr: Harris called upon me, with Mr: J. S. Smith this morning— In the Evening we had visits from Messrs: Plumer & Martin, and also from Monsieur de Rumigny, of the french Embassy.— I sent to Mr: Harris, my letter and the Packets for Professor Fischer at Moscou— Mr: Krehmer also called upon me, and lent me an English newspaper, with a speech of Mr Pinkney at a dinner.

6. I called this morning upon Mr: J. S. Smith, and took him to visit the foreign Ministers— We were received by General Pardo, the Chevalier de Bray, the Chevalier Brancia, Mr: Krabbe at the Baron de Blome’s, Count Schenk—at the other places we left Cards— Mr: Six also received us— And Mr: Krehmer, where I called to leave the Paper which he lent me last Evening— At General Pardo’s we met Count Einsiedel, who shewed us the parting present, he has just received from the Emperor— A Snuff box, with his portrait, encircled with diamonds— Worth as General Pardo says sixteen thousand Rubles.— After paying all these visits we walk’d on the Palace quay—about four, I returned home— Mr: Harris called upon us in the Evening, for half-an-hour.

7. At ten this morning I called at the Office of Mr: Grootten, who accompanied me to the Alexandrofsk Manufactory of which he is the superintendant— A manufactory for spinning Cotton yarn; under the patronage of the Empress-mother— The buildings are about 7 wersts or 5 miles from the City, on the banks of the Neva, beyond the monastery of St: Alexander Newsky. The establishment is under the direction of a Mr: Wilson, an Englishman— There are four or five hundred carding, spinning, and winding machines, which are kept at work, by three Steam Engines, variously constructed, according to the recent improvements upon that great mechanical invention— There is also connected with the establishment a manufactory of Cotton Stockings; where they also wove silk Stockings, while the silk was to be procured— The needles—Cards—and much of the machinery are made within the manufactory— The labour is executed by about five hundred foundling children, nearly an equal number of both sexes; and most of whom are taken at the age of eight, nine, or ten years from the foundling Hospitals of St: Petersburg and of Moscow— They remain here, the boys untill 21. and the girls untill 25 years of age, unless sooner married— They then have liberty to quit the establishment or to remain connected with it at their option. They have apartments accommodated for the married couples, of which there are now about twenty-five; and they are increasing— The institution having existed not more than twelve years, it has only been within four or five that the marriages began to take place— Of the earliest, almost all the children died, and even now a small proportion of those that are born are likely to live— This mortality is attributed to the ignorance of the Parents— But the confinement of the chambers allowed to the families—their extreme poverty— The want of cleanliness, and the almost pestilential air which I found in them sufficiently accounted in my mind for the fact.— In two of the family apartments I saw Russian Cradles; which are a sort of hammock suspended by four small cords from the end of an elastic pole, fastened by the other end near the head of the bed— It hangs about four feet from the floor, and the mother can reach her hand to the pole to rock the cradle, from her bed; by bending the pole at pleasure. It is a very clumsy contrivance, and the child must be always in danger of falling to the floor— An accident which four times in five must prove fatal— The working foundlings themselves look for the most part wretchedly, and very unwholsome— Of two hundred and forty girls, from ten to twenty-five years of age, I scarcely saw one that could be called handsome; and very few, not positively ugly. When we arrived they were just going to dinner— The girls in a long room with tables on the two sides and a passage-way between them— The girls were all standing between the bench and the table; with their faces towards the little image of the virgin hanging at the wall, at the other end of the Hall, and chanting Grace before meat— At that furthest end the floor of the room was raised a step higher and a separate small table was placed at which about twenty of the girls took their seats— Their fare was the same as at the other tables— But to be seated there is an honorary distinction, for particular industry and good conduct.— The dining hall of the boys is of the same form and dimensions a story higher— But there were not more than nine or ten, at their table of distinction— The plates and dishes of the girls were of wood; those of the boys of pewter— Their dinner was a thin turnip soup, and a dish of boiled buckwheat, of the consistency of hasty-pudding,
Their bread rye, and their drink Quas— They are served at table by invalids belonging to the establishment, and who have no other duty— They have school-rooms where at certain hours of leisure and on Sunday mornings they are taught to read, write, and cypher.— They attend public worship at a Church in the neighbourhood the priest of which gives them also occasional religious instruction at the buildings of the institution— The girls all sleep in one long bed-chamber, where there are four rows of beds the whole length of the room, and in several recesses three or four rows more— Its appearance was neat—the bedding all clean—but the air was not good— That of the boys bed-chambers which were in two or three Stages, of a large square hall, with inside staircases to the second & third stage, was much worse—almost insupportable— Mr: Wilson told us it had not been ventilated the whole Winter— By the regulations they must all be in bed before 10 at Night, and rise by 6. in the morning— Their task of work is twelve hours a day, and for any extra work which they choose to do, they are paid— The girls and boys are kept very carefully separate, and although marriages between them are encouraged, yet Mr: Grootten says not a single accident has yet happened— Is this owing to Constitutional coldness?—to the continence of hard labour and penurious subsistence, or to the perfection of subserviency secured by their mode of breeding and education?— Perhaps to all the causes combined with the severity of the climate, and the rigour of the regulations— The machinery has been very expensive— And before the introduction of the Steam-engines, which is only within four or five years, it was kept at work also with great expence— French and German projectors, devised a number of water-wheels, which after the waste of much time and money were found utterly useless— Then came a Mr: Gascoigne, an Englishman, of great mechanical genius, the inventor of the sort of great guns now called Carronades, but which from him were in the first instance called Gasconades— Some unsuccessful speculative inventions had impaired his fortune in England and he had come to Russia where he was employed at the head of a manufactory of iron, some 150 or 200 Wersts from St: Petersburg, when the Direction of this Institution was also put into his hands— He introduced horse-mills to work the machines; a great improvement upon the former processes, but which still left the establishment so expensive that they could not vie with the cheapness of the English manufactures— Mr: Gascoigne, had one third of the profits from the sales, and accumulated a great fortune, of which he died possessed a few years since— He had introduced Mr: Wilson as his assistant in the direction, and since his death Mr: Wilson has his place; but without his emoluments— He has introduced the Steam engines, which have much reduced the expence of the works, and since the War with England, followed by the prohibition of English Goods, this manufacture is in a flourishing condition— But Mr: Wilson has no pay— Nothing but occasional presents, leaving him in a state of anxiety and suspense, with regard to his future prospects—and the order of St: Wolodimir which he received last year from the Emperor, as a mark of his favour.— There are twelve different kinds of machines used in the process of carding and spinning the yarn— But three or four of them are employed in effecting a modification of the Cotton which might be accomplished by one, and Mr: Wilson has invented a machine for that purpose, which is now just beginning to work— There is also much of the labour still done by the hand which might be done by machinery; particularly the wiring of the leather, for the carding machines— I mentioned to Mr: Wilson the American invention for this purpose, of which he told me that he had heard before— They have also here various small machines for making up the yarn into packages, for sending away— The Reels wind off seven threads of a given length which are fastened together, & form the first combination of the prepared article—a number of these gatherings according to the fineness of the yarn forms a skain— The skain is weighed, and according to the number of skains to a pound is numbered from twelve to twenty— The skains of the same numbers are weighed in parcels of ten pounds, and from the scales are put into a hollow squared steel press, in which they
are screwed down into as small a compass, as the hand of the workman can press them—then they are taken out in a cube apparent solid, and made into packages of brown paper tied up with twine— These are deposited upon shelves in the place where they are made up, for ten days together— After which the ten days work is all removed at a time to the warehouse of the manufactory; ready to be taken away by the traders from Moscow and other parts of the Country, who purchase it by whole sale, and take it here at the manufactory— Very little of it is taken at St: Petersburg— Besides the Cotton they also spin some coarse thread from flax— A material to which Mr. Grootten wishes that the whole manufactory were confined; because the flax is the produce of the Country itself.— After spending about four hours in going over the different parts of this Establishment, I returned with Mr: Grootten to the City, and left him at his house— I dined with the Baron de Blome, and a company of about twenty—foreign Ministers—the two Narischkin’s, the Grand Veneur, and the Grand Maître des Ceremonies—Mr: d’Alopeus—Count St: Julien, &c— In the Evening, after my return home, Mr: J. S. Smith called, for half an hour— Mr: Krehmer sent me some English newspapers.

8. I went at twelve O’Clock this day, with Mrs: Adams and Catherine to the Hermitage Palace; with a view to see its curiosities. I had given notice to Mr: Labensky, the Superintendant, who came down from his apartments for a quarter of an hour, and who ordered a servant to attend us the remainder of the time— While we were in the apartments the Empress pass’d through them; as did Prince Galitzin, and the Grand Maréchal Count Tolstoy— We were nearly four hours there, and Mrs: Adams was very much fatigued. The multiplicity of objects to be seen is so great that it always produces confusion in my mind— It would be most expedient to visit different parts of this palace at different times, but in methodical order.— I distinguished however a number of things this day, which had escaped my particular attention before— Noticed a number of new pictures; and remarked the collection of Coins of various Countries.— If only the things of bad taste, and the indifferent pictures were removed, it would be like the weeding of a garden. The useful plants would be more distinctly perceived, and thicker; though the whole number were less.— This Evening we were invited to a party at Mr: Krehmer’s— The Gentlemen went; but the Ladies and myself sent apologies.

9. We were all invited to spend the day at the French Ambassador’s, at Kamminoi-ostrow. I went with Catherine at 3. O’Clock— Mrs: Adams being unwell did not go.— It was the last of the ice-hill parties for the Season; and with rain, snow, thaw and frost they were in a condition which made the sliding down almost impossible. Many of the Ladies and Gentlemen however tried them—the company was unusually numerous—nearly a hundred persons— The foreign legations— The Ambassador’s particular Russian friends, and a numerous accession of the Narischkin’s; with the Grand Maître des Ceremonies, and his family.— Count N. Soltikoff was also there, and I paid him for the Flora Rossica, which he procured for me— We came home early in the Evening— Mr: Rayneval, with whom I had some conversation at dinner says that the Emperor Alexander, will not have his head on his coins because he thinks it a mark of vanity— I had also conversation with Mr: Six, and Count St: Julien.

10. Visit this morning from the Chevalier de Bray, who invited the family to an Evening party at his house next Saturday— I walked on the Moika and Catherine Canal; but the walking is now very bad, as the snow and ice is in the process of disappearing—the Streets accordingly are very wet and muddy— It scarcely freezes now even in the Night— We had Cards and Chess this Evening.

11. As the time for the breaking up of the Ice is now approaching, when Captain Beckford will sail as soon as possible, for Boston, I am to think of executing the various Commissions which were entrusted to me by my friends in America— I called this morning upon Messrs: Glukoff and requested them to procure the sheeting for Mrs: Welsh, for my mother, and for Mrs: Cranch—to pack it up, & direct it to the care of Mr: Gray— And I left a letter for Mr: Gray to go with it. Mr: Glukoff informed me that they had accounts of six American vessels having already pass’d the Sound; five of which are destined for this place— I afterwards called upon Mr: Telisius, and requested his aid to procure all the Volumes of the Transactions of the Academy of Sciences at St: Petersburg, necessary to complete the Collection for the Library of Harvard University— He promised me to mention it at the Conference of the Academy, and give me an early answer— He shewed me a letter he had just received from Mr: Pallas, who is in Crimea— He still complains of the neglect of Sciences at the present day— The age of Catherine he says is past— Excepting Mr: Fuss and Mr: Schubert, there are no learned Academicians— Pallas is Gone— Gmelin and Guldenstaedt are dead— Storch is a Courtier, who writes panegyrics upon the reigning Sovereign, and celebrates the glory and prosperity of Russia, under Alexander the great— The rest are all Russians—that is, nothing— The academy is daily declining, and supports itself now principally by printing books for individual authors. He shewed me also a press, which he has had made for colouring prints— It is precisely upon the principle of Watt’s copying press; only larger— He shewed me also a number of coloured prints for Gmelin’s Historia Fucorum, which he has taken upon vellum paper, to send to Dr: Barton— But he says they cost five Rubles a print— He had sent the volume to Dr: Barton with the plates struck on Russian paper and uncoloured. Dr: Barton complained of the badness of their execution; and he sends him these to shew him what can be done— Mr: Telisius was the editor of the German Edition of Pallas’s Voyages. I enquired of him for Pallas’s work on the various dialects of the Russian Empire; but he said if it was to be procured it would only be by advertising for it in the newspapers— That the work was incomplete, and is now to be continued by Mr: Adelung.— I found with Mr: Telisius a Mr: Gauler the engraver; whose pupils are employed in engraving his designs for the voyage of Krusenstern—after leaving him I walked round the quay and the Fontanka, home— At seven in the Evening we attended the first Lecture of Mr: Boucher, upon maritime and commercial Law— He was about three quarters of an hour reading it. His audience consisted principally of persons belonging to the Departments of foreign Affairs and of Commerce— Count Romanzoff, and Count Kotschubey were both there— The Lectures are to be on Monday and Thursday Evenings at 7. O’Clock— The introductory lecture was panegyrical upon the Emperor Alexander, and said much of Mr: Boucher himself— Count Romanzoff it seems had insisted upon the suppression of an Eulogium upon him which it had contained— With this there was an Oratorical amplification of the merits of Commerce, and a rapid sketch of the antient history of Commerce— Noticing the Rhodian Laws—the Consolato del Mare—The Judgments of Oleron and Wisbuy—and the Ordinance of Lewis 14— The Lecture finished soon after 8— Cards and Chess amused the remainder of the Evening.

12. My eldest son George is this day, if it please God, nine years old— The day brought with it a mixture of pleasing, and of melancholy sensations— The comfort and enjoyment of my life, to which his birth so essentially contributed has been constantly promoted by the pleasures and occupations of his nurture and education, and of that of his younger brothers— But now, we are separated from him, and from another of our children—from the enjoyment of their Society; and from the means of aiding their improvement— May the blessing of Heaven, supply the place of parents to them— I went this morning to several booksellers—Etter—Klosterman—Leznowski, to seek for Russian and Slavonian Dictionaries and Grammars. I found
several, but at such excessive prices that I purchased none of them— Dined with Mr: Six— The french Ambassador, several others of the foreign Ministers, M: de Laval and M. Dournoff were there— M. de Rayneval and the Ambassador after dinner gave me their opinions upon the state of this Country, and its principal personages with much freedom— Like all other foreigners here, they speak of the Country very unfavourably— The only exception to this remark that I have yet found, is Mr: Harris— Evening at home, employed as usual. (Charles 2 f. 10. inches.)

13. I went again this morning in search of Russian Dictionaries and Grammars, of which I found a number; and made some purchases for Mr: Webster, and Harvard College— I was so long in the cold shops that I found myself with a severe rhumatism the remainder of the day— Mrs: Adams was all day very ill, with a nervous headache.— Mr: J. S. Smith was here in the morning, and Mr: Harris in the Evening.

14. Taking my usual walk this morning, I met General Pardo, and walked about an hour with him. His Conversation is very agreeable— His learning profound; and his taste in the fine Arts enlightened and elegant— But he passes not a little of his time, translating Horace into Greek— I doubt whether this can even be called Nugae-Canorae— Yet what right have I to reflect upon it? How do I pass my own time?— In Politics, his views are extensive, and in many respects correct— But his opinions are so much biassed by his prejudices and his Passions, that no dependence can be placed upon him— His belief, is the child of his feelings, and his information is more inaccurate than that of any man that I have met here; moving in that sphere— Just as we parted the Emperor pass’d us in his sleigh—driven by a mushik with a white shaft trotting horse, and a galopping furieux— We went this Evening to a small dancing party at the Chevalier de Bray’s—the Ladies did not go; Mrs: Adams being too unwell— I played at chess with Mr: Maclure; and came home immediately after supper, at half pact one in the morning.

15. I attended this morning the service of the Greek ceremonial in the Church of St: Isaac— In some respects it differed from those that I have witnessed heretofore— There were only two officiating Priests— The choir of singers at the left hand of the Chancel was small, but the singing as usual excellent— There was one ceremony, which I could not ascertain whether the administration of the Communion, or of baptism. There were two vessels, as if containing, one the bread and the other the wine—the former borne by the inferior priest upon his head—the other; a cup carried in the hand by the other priest, raised to the level of his eyes— The cup only was administered, and that only to the infants of a number of women, who held them in their arms—on the whole I concluded it was baptism— The subordinate priest read, nearly half-an-hour from a book—but whether it was a homily or chapters from the Bible I could not ascertain— After the service was over that which I took to be baptism was repeated to two women with infants who were not there in time for the first— They stood about the centre of the church—the inferior priest read to them from the book for some time— They then went up to the balustrade. The inferior Priest there took their children, successively from the mothers, carried them to the Superior in the Sanctuary, and a moment after returned, and gave them back— The mothers appeared delighted to have obtained the blessings— The multitude of self-crossings—the profound and constantly repeated bows, the prostrations upon the earth & kissing of the floor witnessed the depth of Superstition, in which this people is plunged perhaps more forcibly than I had seen before. The isle of the Church where alone the service can be heard was crowded, but there appeared to be only people in the lowest classes of Society, moozhiks and common Soldiers there— A collection for charity was made during the service, and beggar-boys and girls were going about and asking alms, frequently during the performance— I saw one little girl, obtain several single copeeks, principally from the soldiers. The collection was received on tin Canisters with
narrow holes on the lids, to let in the money— But there were several copeek and two copeek pieces on the lid itself, and some of those who put on it two copeek pieces, took single copeeks from it in exchange— In the centre of this Church, which is built in the regular shape of a Cross, the trophies lately atchieved from the Enemies of Russia are suspended. They are not numerous— I saw one English flag there; but I know not where it was taken— The Pictures, as in their other Churches, are some good, and some very bad— I suppose those the worst executed are the most esteemed for sanctity. I walked round the Quay and the Fontanka, home— About six miles— Mr: J. S. Smith called upon us this Evening. Mrs: Adams was very unwell all day; but better in the Evening— I read Massillon’s Sermon upon religious presumption—the last of his Carême, and a good Sermon; though not among his best.

16. Mr: Six paid me a visit this morning, and we had a long conversation upon political subjects. He is the exact counterpart of General Pardo— The Emperor Napoleon is his idol— He once told me he was afraid, Napoleon before he died would take upon him to demand the adoration of mankind, as being something superhuman— This idea, he said, was entertained by the whole family of the Bonaparte’s, and as strongly by his own king Louis, as by any of them— I do not know whether Napoleon will ever assume the God, or not; but if he should Mr: Six would be one of the most devout, of his Priests— His subjugation of Soul is complete— But he is a man of great political information; of long experience; of better principles than most Statesmen, of this or any other day; of good intentions—of good disposition—anxiously desirous of the esteem of others, and especially of those whose judgment he fears— Conscious of compliances with the Times, which stubborn Virtue cannot approve his mind is in a frequent if not continual struggle to justify himself to his own feelings— The worship of Napoleon is thus in some sort necessary to his quiet— It helps him to apologies of which he feels the want— When his chain galls him he looks at it, and takes comfort in the thought that it is gold— Pardo, bites at his with the fury of a phrenetic, but without having the strength to break it— Six’s information is usually more accurate than that of the General— He is not so much blinded by his Passions— He loves to tell Secrets, and often communicates with injunctions of profound secrecy, the common rumours of the Exchange.— The day I dined with him last week, he told me that the Rotterdam Gazette that day arrived had brought accounts of a french officer having landed in England, who was said to be the bearer of propositions for a pacific negotiation— That by a private letter he was informed, that this Officer was Marshall Duroc— This however he begged me not to mention, as he had communicated it to no other person but the Ambassador and myself— The next morning Mr: J. S. Smith asked me, if I had heard the report current upon the Exchange two days before that Duroc had landed in England, upon an errand of Peace— The Hamburg news-paper on Saturday brought the report and its refutation. This day Mr: Six observed to me that it appeared Duroc was not the man; though he had been announced in the Morning Chronicle.— His visit was so long that I had time only for a short walk— Dined at Baron Blome’s, and saw many of his maps, of which he has a fine collection— Mr: Montréal had called upon me this morning to remind me, that Mr: Boucher’s second lecture would be at 7. this Evening.— It was a quarter past seven before we got there, and he had begun about ten minutes before— His subject was relative to bills of exchange— He traced the etymology, and explained the meaning of the word aval, which is used at the bottom of french bills, and he insisted much upon the necessity of fixing with the most accurate precision the meaning of all terms of art.— His Lecture was not written; but he held in his hand a small paper containing apparently minutes of the points upon which he touched— He was less than half an hour, and observed that this and perhaps three or four of the next Lectures would not be very interesting— But after that he should
enter upon topics of importance— Mr: Harris spent part of the Evening with us— I engaged him to endeavour to get some further information concerning the recent English negotiation here, and the state of affairs between Russia, & France, which is peculiarly interesting to us.

17. After passing most of the morning in writing I walked, and made some purchases at booksellers shops— I find them varying very much in their prices. I procured at the Court Bookseller Alici’s handsomely half-bound Maudru’s Grammar, for which at Klosterman’s they asked me twenty Roubles unbound— I gave for it, but fifteen— I bought at another shop Storch’s Picture of the Russian Empire, and Guldenstaedt’s travels— I procured also a number of copper plates of the Russian manuscript characters. Finished reading the third volume of the Voyage de deux François dans le Nord de l’Europe— A book of some wit; and more malice—written with ill humour rather than critical discernment—always eager to seize the opportunity of finding fault, and reluctant at approbation— The writers appear to have come to spy the nakedness of the land; and wherever they can discover it, to delight in exposing it— Their account of an abominable club at Moscou is said to have had too much foundation, though in its details it must be exaggerated— Evening at home.

18. As Count Romanzoff had neither sent nor written to me concerning the letter which I told him I had received from the Abbé Brzozowski, after waiting some weeks, I took it for granted that his silence implied consent that the letter should be delivered. I accordingly sent it last week, and received immediately from him a letter of thanks, with the title of Le Père General des Jèsuites, a personage whom I did not know to be still existing— He paid me this morning a visit, and renewed his thanks for my care of the letter, with the request that I would take charge of his answer; which I readily promised to do—the letter itself was from America— He asked me many questions about America—told me that Bishop Carrol had formerly been a Jesuit, and asked if I knew the Prince Galitzin who is a Jesuit, and in America— His namesake Prince Alexander Galitzin, the Procureur du St: Signode once spoke of him to me. I wrote to the Secretary of State; to send by the first vessel that will go to America from Reval— Went with Mr: Gray to the Russian Book-stall at the shops.— Received a Note from Count Romanzoff, with two copies of a French translation of the Imperial Ordinance on the new organisation of the Council of State— Evening at home; chiefly employed in reading the Voyages de Deux Français, dans le Nord de l’Europe. Vol: 4.

19. Mr: Hennings paid me this morning a visit to take leave— He goes this evening for Berlin where he is to be the Danish Chargé des Affaires— He told me that Monsieur Tettard the French Ambassador’s private Secretary was also going this Evening for Paris; and the Baron de Mareschal Secretary of Count St: Julien for Vienna— I rode out this morning with Mrs: Adams in search of furniture; but found none that would exactly suit us— It took up almost the whole morning— I called at Klosterman the bookseller’s— He had promised me to enquire for the work of Pallas on the Languages spoken in the Russian Provinces— He has been unable to procure it— That is his shopkeeper, or partner; for Klosterman himself knew nothing of the existence of such a work— At seven this Evening, I attended Mr: Boucher’s Lecture— His method this Evening was different from that of either of his former lectures— Seated at his own table, he had one of his auditory, a Mr: Fringan, who is employed in the Office of foreign Affairs seated at another table on his right hand— Mr: Fringan read from a manuscript two or three paragraphs of text; untill the professor stop’d him by a sign, or by laying hold of his arm, and made an extemporaneous comment about as long as the text— This was alternated for about half an hour; untill Mr: Fringan found so much difficulty in reading the manuscript, that the Professor, put off the lecture untill a fair copy of it
should be made out— He announced a Séance extraordinaire, for Saturday Evening at 7. O’Clock, when he should state a question upon commercial Law, to be discussed in writing by the pupils attendant upon his Lectures. He also announced, that many persons having requested to see his introductory discourse, all of whom he had been obliged to refuse, he had determined to open a subscription for printing it— The cost would only be one or two roubles for each subscriber, and the Discourse would be very useful in the future attendance upon the course— This new mode of lecturing, is not agreeable to the hearer— It is much too desultory; and naturally leads to tedious repetitions— The Comment upon one paragraph consisting very frequently of the text of that which was to succeed.— The most interesting parts of the Lecture were a comparison between the principle of doing as you would be done by; and of not doing as you would not be done by, the positive and negative maxim, which different writers he said had laid down as the foundation of morality and of law— A discussion of contradictory assertions by Voltaire and Montesquieu, respecting the right of the Venitian nobility to trade— A panegyric upon the code of Roman Law, upon a history of it by Terrasson— The lecture was finished before 8 O’Clock— Mr: J. S. Smith and Mr: Maclure paid us visits, the latter part of the Evening— Catherine Johnson was confined to her chamber and bed by illness.

20. Dr: Galloway was here and lent me some English newspapers, of the last days in February and of the first in March. I passed the greater part of the Evening in reading them— The snow and the ice of the streets is melting gradually away, so that the quays are the only places where the walking is good.— I went to the foundery upon that of the Neva; which from the Palace corner is a full mile and a half long.

21. The streets are scarcely passable for walkers; and a steady rain almost the whole of this morning prevented me from going out the whole day. Mr: Six called and paid me a long visit, in which we had much conversation. He told me several anecdotes, characteristic of the Grand Duke and Czarowitz Constantine.— The stories told of such personages in this Country are all so extraordinary that I am always cautious of believing them. But from the character of the stories it is possible at least to collect the opinions generally entertained of the persons concerning whom they are told— Mr: Six related some transactions with a woman, named Araujo, which are altogether incredible.— The interruptions which I experienced prevented me from writing much— Catherine is still very unwell— The length of this day here, from Sunrise to Sunset, is equal to that of the longest day at Boston.

22. I went successively this morning to the St: Nicholas, the Assumption and the Great Roman Catholic Church, to attend the Service of the day— The Church of St: Nicholas was open, and about twenty shrines were lighted up with tapers hanging before them; and many worshippers at several of them, crossing and prostrating themselves according to the manner of the Country, before them— The Shrines in general were gaudily dress’d out— The only one particularly remarkable, contained a portrait of St: Nicolas, with twelve scenes, I suppose from the legend of his life, painted in miniature round the figure of his person, which was only a kit cat. It was very well painted, and in a handsome frame— But there was no public service performing— The annunciation and assumption churches were not even open— And the Roman Catholic church service was finished just as I went to go in— I met a crowd of people coming from it; many of them with palm branches in their hands— The branches were all budded, and almost in leaf— They must therefore have been raised in green houses— It is by the old style reckoning used here Palm-Sunday; though in every other part of Christendom, where these festivals are observed it is Easter-Sunday— I had never before observed the Commemoration of the day by carrying palm-branches, of which I have this day witnessed great quantities. Its allusion is to the entrance of Jesus Christ into Jerusalem—for which, see St: John’s Gospel Ch. 12. v. 1. 12. and 13.— St: John is the only one of the Evangelists who mentions that the branches of the trees were of palm.— After returning, I
I passed the remainder of the day at home, and read Massillon’s Sermon, upon submission to the Will of God— It is the first of the Volume, entitled Mysteries, and was preached on the day to commemorate the purification of the Virgin Mary— This it seems among the Roman Catholics is one of the Holy Mysteries; and this Sermon explains how it is mysterious— The example of the Virgin is repeatedly urged as an argument for submission to the divine Will, but the assignment of her motives, which should operate alike upon others is admirable— I place it among the best of the Bishop’s discourses.

23. Mr: J. S. Smith called upon me this morning, and brought me a letter from a Mr: Siegfried at Königsberg in Prussia; requesting to be appointed American Consul there— He referr’d to Mr: Smith for his character; for which Mr: Smith did not chuse to vouch— I have however no authority to appoint consuls in Prussia— I walked on the Palace Quay— The Streets are scarcely passable. The thaw now continues night and day— We had this day several April showers— At 7. in the Evening I attended Mr: Boucher’s fourth lecture— It was upon the law of Nations—the Civil—Municipal—Public and Private Laws— He contested the position of Burlamaqui, that the Law of Nations is merely an application of the Law of Nature— He interspersed his lecture with various anecdotes, and continued as desultory as heretofore— He gave me a small printed pamphlet— A Dissertation of Mr: Fringan, upon the stones that fall from the atmosphere— His lecturing room was so warm, and the air in it so confined, that Mr: Gray on coming out of it nearly fainted away— The lecture was longer than usual; and the professor gave notice that on account of the approaching holidays his next lecture would not be, untill a Week from next Thursday.

24. Mr: Harris called upon me this morning— He has been several days unwell; and confined to his chamber— Taking this day my customary walk, I met the Emperor on the Palace Quay— He stop’d me; took me by the hand, and accosting me in English, said he heard I had been ill.— I had never before heard him speak English; but he speaks it very well. He afterwards told me that he had seen my boy, and that he was a fine boy— I said I had heard the child had had the honour of seeing him, and would remember it all his life— It is the Emperor’s daily practice to ride or walk; and when walking he stops and speaks familiarly to any of his acquaintance, and often to people whom he does not know, even of the lowest order of his subjects— Mr: Maclure and Mr: Plumer were here and spent part of the Evening with us— I have again begun to learn the characters of the Russian Alphabet: and feel a reviving inclination to learn something of the language— Yet it is of so little use elsewhere that it seems to be time and labour lost. I began however this day upon Charpentier’s Grammar.

25. Mr: Harris wrote me a note requesting the form of a discharge in full of all demands, which he proposes to take from Mr: Donovan; which I accordingly sent him— He called upon us this Evening with Mr: J. S. Smith, and brought me some manuscript papers of the compilation respecting the armed neutrality, which is intended to be published— I finished reading the fourth volume of the two French travellers— It contains an explanation of the severity which they observe respecting every thing Russian— They say that the Russians speak ill of all Strangers, who come into the Country, and to their certain knowledge did so of them.— These books contain in substance not much more than Coxe and the other travellers— The buildings, and Cabinets and Manufactures of St: Petersburg and Moscou— The Customs of the Country which are exposed to superficial observation. Some historical real or fictitious anecdotes of the Emperors & Empresses from the time of Peter the Great— Lists of the Russian Army and Navy— Weights, Measures and Coins— This is nearly all that they contain. They furnish very little knowledge of Russia.

26. Wrote a note this morning to Count Romanzoff, mentioning that Mr: J. S. Smith and Mr: Gray, were desirous of being presented at Court when the occasion should present itself— I afterwards called upon Monsieur de Maisonneuve, to enquire whether there would be a Court held this or the next week— He said there probably would next Monday; being the day after Easter; and that it would probably be the last untill the Autumn— He told me he had been very unwell almost the whole Winter.— I afterwards visited Count Bussche, and M. de Laval; but they were not at home. Met Mr: Maclure and walked with him on the Quay— He conversed on the subject of France— He is a Napoleonite. He says that the condition of the People in France has been improved by the Revolution in the proportion of 7 to 25. that the Conscription, is not felt by the great mass of the people, as an oppression at all— That it bears hard only upon the rich— That there is as much liberty of Speech in France, as in any other part of Europe excepting Sweden— That Napoleon’s System, is to establish all over Europe, Governments in which the People will haveconfidence— He does admit, though with seeming reluctance, that Republican Sentiments are not now fashionable in France— But he considers the liberation of the People, from the burthens of feudal servitude, as securing them privileges, which many accumulated ages of the despotism which has taken place will not take from them or countervail— Evening, reading Bülow, and at Chess.

27. This day being Good-Friday, by the Old-Style Calendar, I went to the Church of St: Nicholas, and heard the Service of the day; which I did not perceive however to differ from the ordinary mass— Their mode of worship here is such that one service can be attended only by very few persons— The Churches are built in the form of a Cross; thusThe place where the service is performed is at one of the ends as at (a.) which is railed off by a low balustrade— There are neither benches nor chairs The people stand in the isle, and every individual must have space enough around him to cross himself incessantly, to bow himself down almost to the earth about once in five seconds, and to prostrate himself on hands, knees and forehead, according to the ardour of his devotion. In the mean time beggars are circulating through the crowd to catch the critical moment of charitable feeling, and receive the donation of his copeek— I saw one this day of the most squalid appearance; in tatters which scarcely hung together upon his body, but with a leather bag, half-full of the alms he was receiving, and giving single copeeks in exchange for two copeek pieces— But the donors themselves appeared as much objects for charity, as those to whom they gave it— In general; both at the Nicolaï and Isaac’s Churches, I saw scarcely a person attending that was above the class of ordinary muzhiks— I afterwards went to the Roman Catholic Church, where I found a Priest in the Pulpit preaching a Sermon in the Polish Language. He was very animated in his discourse, and seemingly pathetic; there was a portable wooden crucifix placed in a groove at his left hand by the side of his pulpit— While speaking with much vehemence, he seized this crucifix, held it forward to the people, many of whom immediately fell upon their knees and bowed their heads to the floor before it, while he continued with increasing exertion of lungs and muscles, to apostrophize them upon the object represented to them upon the cross, untill the end of his Sermon— After it was finished I returned home. Mr Harris and Mr: Malbone called upon me— Mr: Harris also dined and pass’d the Evening with us.

28. Count Einsiedel, late the Saxon Minister at this Court paid me a visit, and presented Mr: Rosenzweig as the Chargé d’Affaires from his Court— The Count is going as Saxon Minister to Paris— I received from Count Romanzoff a notification, that Mr: J. S. Smith, and Mr: Gray, would be presented to their Imperial Majesties next Monday after the Mass—and from the Grand-maitre des Cérémonies Narishkin a notice that there will be a Court held next Monday, being the second day of the Easter Holidays, at Noon— Mr: Harris, and Mr: J. S. Smith pass’d part of the Evening with us.

29. Easter Sunday— The greatest Holiday of the Russian Calendar— It celebrates the Resurrection of Christ— The Ceremonies, as at Christmas begin at Midnight. Mr: Everett and Mr: Smith attended at the Church of St: Isaac, where a service of about two hours was performed, partly without the Church round which the Priests went three times successively in procession, and partly within it, where was a representation of the Sepulchre from which the Saviour arose— The crowd of People attending was excessive— At Midnight, the signal was given by the firing of a Cannon at the fortress; which was soon after followed by several others; and at two or three subsequent periods of the night a salvo of twenty-five or thirty guns was fired— The midnight service is performed at all the Churches, and the Emperor and Imperial family attend at their Chapel— Among the customs of the Country is that of embracing one another at this period, and all the people who attend at the Court Chapel are admitted to kiss the Emperor’s sleeve, and the Empress’s hand— It is also the custom to make presents upon this day, and particularly of eggs— The muzhik’s present real eggs, hard-boiled and died red with log-wood; for which they receive roubles— Persons of higher standing present eggs of sugar, glass, gilt-wood porcellain, marble, and almost every other substance, and of various dimensions. Many of them made into cups, or boxes, filled with sugar-plums— Others with paintings and biscuit figures upon them, emblematical of the crucifixion and resurrection— Some of these eggs are made to cost a hundred roubles or upwards— Servants present these eggs to their Masters and receive presents in return as at the new year— Friends present them to one another and embrace— It is a mode of gallantry, allowable towards Ladies, by Gentlemen of their intimate acquaintance; and in return for an egg, the Gentleman is entitled to the return of a salutation— The parade was this morning more splendid than usual; and of longer continuance. I went to the Roman Catholic Church and heard Mass performed. There appeared during the day time to be no service at the Greek Churches— The Streets all day were crowded with People— New dresses—equipages—liveries were driving round the City, and met at every turn— The whole circle of Court visits by cards must be paid, as on new-year’s day; and the visits in person are more numerous than at that time— I paid four or five visits in person, leaving Cards.— The Court attendants came to pay and receive their Compliments as usual— I met Mr: Harris, and walked with him on the Square of St: Isaac and the line— On the Square are a number of Fair shows, under temporary shelters erected for the occasion, and the common people were amusing themselves in whirligig Chairs, and Swings— There are four Chairs to a wheel, which contain two persons each, and move round in a perpendicularly circular motion— But it is very slow, and kept up only by a muzhik pushing forward each of the chairs as it descends— The Swings are a plank suspended by four cords fixed at its ends, from a gallows standing over it; on the plank are two Seats for two persons each— At each end of the plank a man, or woman standing, and holding by the cords which pass from the plank to the cross piece of the gallows, keep the swing in motion by the exertion of their muscles, and by changing the centre of gravity at the moment when the swing reaches its highest elevation on each side— This they do, by simply bending their knees, and thus shortening their own length— And I saw at least as many swings thus kept in motion by women, as by men.— The Mass at the Catholic Church was remarkable only as it was long— The music was exquisite— The Sermon, in Italian, had been preached before the Mass— Mr: Everett and Mr: Gray heard part of it— Mr: Smith dined abroad.

30. At twelve O’Clock I went to the Palace, with all the Gentlemen, connected with the Legation— It was between one and two when the Court commenced; which as usual was over in a very few minutes— The Empress mother is the readiest of all the imperial family upon these occasions, at Conversation— None of them speak more than one or two Sentences to each of the foreign Ministers; and to part of the persons presented. They do not speak at-all to any one else— The Empress told me she had seen my Son, who was a charming boy.— The Empress Mother spoke as usual of Mrs: Adams and her children in America; and the Emperor asked me, if my health was entirely restored— All talked about the weather (it was snowing—) and about the superb Parade, of yesterday Morning.— Mr: J. S. Smith, and Mr: Gray, were presented— After the Court was over we saw the formality of the French Ambassador’s return from Court— His Equipage, a gilt Coach, and six superb horses with two outriders in livery behind, and an ecuyer preceding it, entering the inner Court of the Palace, and went to the door out of which he was to come— He went into the Carriage with M. de Rayneval the first Secretary of the Embassy.— The Carriage then traversed again the Court-yard, on the walk, with two foot men, walking on each-side, who as well as all the out-riders remained uncovered, as they pass’d by the corps de garde; which turn’d out, while the Carriage with the Ambassador in it was traversing the yard— This is the etiquette of the Ambassador’s going to and returning from Court. We all went, as upon New-Year’s day, and had our names written down in the anti-chamber of the Czarovitz and Grand-Duke Constantine— I returned home; undressed, and went to Count Einsiedel’s, with a letter of introduction for him to General Armstrong, which I gave him at his desire— I found him preparing for his departure, and understand that he intends to go, the day after to’morrow— I afterwards walked upon the Palace-quay to the Foundery— Mr: J. S. Smith and Mr: Fisher pass’d part of the Evening with us— I saw at Court, Count John Potocki, who told me he was about to publish something further upon the antient Chronology.

Day. I rise irregularly, between 5 and 10 in the Morning; and scarcely any two days successively at the same hour— Read or write untill breakfast time, which is about ten— From that time, untill 3. in the afternoon, I write when I can— But visits to receive or pay interrupt and often entirely prevent this employment— From 3 to 5. I appropriate to my daily walk; but that is also very often abridged or prevented by the same causes— At 5. we dine— From 6 to 8 or 9. I read, as much as similar interruptions will admit— From nine untill bed-time, we play cards or chess occasionally— From eleven to one in the Morning is the hour at which we retire— Some times half an hour earlier than eleven, and sometimes as much after one— It is now not dark untill ten at Night.
